prose1.value: I. Kissed. A. Girl. And. I. Liked. It.
In a time when the soundtrack to your life is built on a mountain of “firsts:”
First heartbreak: Eric Clapton’s “Wonderful Tonight.”
Those 8 problematically-presented words became a secret anthem — the first time I heard a woman openly singing about another woman.

The first radio station to play “I Kissed a Girl” was Nashville’s 107.5 “The River,” or stereo preset No. 6 in my very inconspicuous first car: a lime green Pontiac Sunfire. When I heard it, I was floored. This? In the “Buckle of the Bible Belt” in a state that, to this day, has some of the most vile anti- queer and transgender laws? I immediately downloaded it and burned a CD.

At 3 minutes long, I could listen to the defiant bass line about 16 times on the 50-minute drive it took to get to the “second-closest” Best Buy two towns over. Driving those extra minutes and that extra town ensured that I could snag the equally inconspicuous flaming pink-boxed first season of L Word without waving a giant rainbow flag and raising any questions about my sexuality. I wasn’t ready. At least not yet.

prose2.value: But, it turned out that “I Kissed a Girl” wasn’t just something I was singing with my car windows rolled up, it was something everyone was scream-singing at the top of their lungs. It was a certified top-of-the-charts bop. I wasn’t fully convinced of mainstream acceptance, but it at least seemed like mainstream permission.

For as groundbreaking as it felt to hear a woman explicitly singing about being with another woman then, it would take another 13 years for a man explicitly singing about being with another man to top the charts.

prose3.value: Then came Lil Nas X’s “MONTERO (Call Me By Your Name).”

This time there’s no drunken permission (“I got so brave, drink in hand”). No hint at a phase or a fling (“You're my experimental game”). No fetishisation of the male gaze. (“I hope my boyfriend don't mind it”).
Just a Black queer artist unapolgetically owning it: “I want that jet lag from fuckin' and flyin', Shoot a child in your mouth while I'm ridin'”
It’s going to be a soundtrack “first” for so many people.

prose4.value: Since Katy Perry’s “gay-for-pay” bop appeared in the year-end Billboard Hot 100 in 2008, there have only been 7 other songs with explicit same-gender lyrics:
Macklemore & Ryan Lewis Featuring Mary Lambert’s “Same Love” (2013)
That’s 0.7%. Eight songs (not even one a year) out of 1,157 unique hits. And ALL of them feature a woman explicitly singing about another woman using words like “she”, “her”, and “girl” — until now.

prose5.value: I’m making some assumptions to say that “MONTERO (Call Me By Your Name)” will appear on the 2021 year-end Billboard Hot 100 charts, but it’s well within reach. Lil Nas X’s queer anthem has already spent 8 weeks on the charts. The No. 100s songs from the last 3 years average about 20 weeks in the Hot 100.

Out queer artists like Janelle Monáe, Frank Ocean, Kelani, Hayler Kiyoko, Troye Sivan, and JoJo Siwa haven’t cracked the year-end Billboard Hot 100 with solo songs yet, but even when queer artists do reach the pinacle of pop mainstream they rarely sing about same-gender relationships.

Between 2008–2020, 135 songs featuring an openly queer artist appeared on the year-end Top 100 charts. Only 5 (3.7%) include explicit same gender lyrics, and 4 of those are performed by openly bisexual women and also include lyrics about opposite-gender relationships like “Bad at Love” where Halsey sings “Got a boy back home in Michigan/Got a girl with California eyes.”

prose6.value: Of course, queer lyrics aren’t limited to same-gender references, but they’re often the most sanitized and direct version that a mainstream audience recognizes and is exposed to.

Artists like Halsey, Lady Gaga, and Cardi B are openly bisexual so singing about relationships with BOTH men and women is queer. And artists like Demi Lovato, Sam Smith, and Miley Cyrus are non-binary or genderfluid, so when they do sing about gender (rarely in Top 100 songs) it’s queer. And there are plenty of other queer lyrics that don’t explicitly reference gender at all.

As someone firmly planted in my queer identity now (I have a wife, we have a rainbow flag in front of our home, I watch a lot of women’s sports) it’s easy for me to catch enuedos, nods, and winks like Lovato’s “Got a taste for the cherry, I just need to take a bite” or Lil Nas X’s “I might bottom on the low, but I top shit,” but thinking back to who I was when I first heard “I Kissed a Girl,” I might not have recognized myself in these songs unless someone pointed a neon rainbow arrow at it.

It reminds me of a line from a Dave Holmes piece about Taylor Swift’s the “vague call for tolerance” that was “You Need to Calm Down:” “...in a bedroom somewhere in the world, some young person is getting a desperately-needed window into a life that suits them, and I am legitimately thrilled for that kid.”
And that’s what music can do. It can be someone’s “hundredth” or “thousandth” or “not-far-enough,” AND it can be someone’s “first.”

method.value: This project began in 2019. We were taunted with songs like Sam Smith and Demi Lovato's “I’m Ready” and Miley Cyrus’ “Midnight Sky” until Lil Nas X released “MONTERO (Call Me By Your Name)” and we were confident in a narrative path forward.

We collected year-end Hot 100 songs from Billboard. Then we researched each artist’s sexual orientation and gender identity with a mixed programmatic/manual approach that looked at Wikipedia pages, news articles, and social media profiles. We built 3 dictionaries: one to flag feminine gendered lyrics like “women”, “girl”, “her”, and “she”; one to flag masculine gendered lyrics like “man”, “boy”, “his”, and “he”; and one to flag relationship lyrics like “love”, “heart”, “kiss”, “sex”.

We used lyrics from an existing corpus and filled in gaps from Genius. Each song was tagged by whether it contained feminined gendered lyrics, masculine gendered lyrics, and relationship lyrics. Then those tags were compared to the artist’s sexual orientation and gender identity. This gave us a set of songs to manually check. From there we listened to A LOT of music to identify the 8 songs with explicit same-gender relationship lyrics. Think we missed anything? Email Jan at jan@pudding.cool.
